mcompanion 0.5.0
  • Reference
  • Changelog

Generate seed parameters of mc-matrices

sim_mcseeds.Rd

Generates suitable seed parameters for an mc-matrix with partially specified spectral properties. Unspecified numeric values are simulated with sim_numbers().

sim_mcseeds(mo = nrow(co), len.block, co, type, argarg = list(0, pi), ...)

Arguments

mo

multi-companion order.
len.block

lengths of the Jordan blocks.
co

seed parameters.
type

types of the eigenvectors, eg. "cp", see Details.
argarg

range for the complex argument.
...

further arguments to be passed on to sim_numbers.

Details

Generates seed parameters for a multi-companion matrix of multi-companion order mo and spectral and other parameters as specified by the arguments. See sim_numbers in package "gbutils" for addtional arguments for control of the distributions of the generated values.

The number of the eigenvectors is inferred from the arguments. It is taken to be sum(len.block), ncol(co) or length(type), depending on which arguments are specified.

type is a character vector specifying the types of the corresponding eigenvectors ("r" for real, "cp" for complex pairs). If type is missing, all vectors are assumed complex of type "cp".

Note that each pair of complex conjugated vectors is represented by a single vector with arguments in the interval (0, pi).

Argument co can be used to specify some of the elements of the result. If co is given if should have the required dimension.

Value

a matrix with mo rows containing the coefficients.

Note

This function is OK when all eigenvalues are simple. Otherwise it should be called with suitably prepared argument co, which may be tricky.

For proper parameterisation, see spec_core for the general case and spec_root0 and spec_root1. The latter two functions handle the most important special cases of the spaces corresponding to zero and unit roots.

TODO: The name of the function, sim_mcseeds, is misleading since it does not do anything specific to mc-matrices. (except the conventions for "type", e.g. each complex pair is represented by one number)

See also

spec_core
